member.summary: Helper class for .

member.name: M:InTheHand.DateTimeOffsetHelper.FromUnixTimeSeconds(System.Int64)
member.summary: Converts a Unix time expressed as the number of seconds that have elapsed since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z to a value.
member.param: A Unix time, expressed as the number of seconds that have elapsed since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z (January 1, 1970, at 12:00 AM UTC). For Unix times before this date, its value is negative.
member.returns: A date and time value that represents the same moment in time as the Unix time.

member.name: M:InTheHand.DateTimeOffsetHelper.FromUnixTimeMilliseconds(System.Int64)
member.summary: Converts a Unix time expressed as the number of milliseconds that have elapsed since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z to a value.
member.param: A Unix time, expressed as the number of milliseconds that have elapsed since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z (January 1, 1970, at 12:00 AM UTC). For Unix times before this date, its value is negative.
member.returns: A date and time value that represents the same moment in time as the Unix time.

member.name: M:InTheHand.DateTimeOffsetHelper.ToUnixTimeSeconds(System.DateTimeOffset)
member.summary: Returns the number of seconds that have elapsed since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z.
member.param: The DateTimeOffset value.
member.returns: The number of seconds that have elapsed since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z.
member.remarks:
Unix time represents the number of seconds that have elapsed since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z (January 1, 1970, at 12:00 AM UTC). It does not take leap seconds into account.
This method first converts the current instance to UTC before returning its Unix time. For date and time values before 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z, this method returns a negative value.

member.name: M:InTheHand.DateTimeOffsetHelper.ToUnixTimeMilliseconds(System.DateTimeOffset)
member.summary: Returns the number of milliseconds that have elapsed since 1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z.
member.param: The DateTimeOffset value.
member.returns: The number of milliseconds that have elapsed since 1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z.
member.remarks:
Unix time represents the number of seconds that have elapsed since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z (January 1, 1970, at 12:00 AM UTC). It does not take leap seconds into account. This method returns the number of milliseconds in Unix time.
This method first converts the current instance to UTC before returning the number of milliseconds in its Unix time. For date and time values before 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z, this method returns a negative value.

member.name: T:InTheHand.Devices.Geolocation.Geocoordinate
member.summary: Contains the information for identifying a geographic location.

member.name: P:InTheHand.Devices.Geolocation.Geocoordinate.Accuracy
member.summary: The accuracy of the location in meters.
member.value: The accuracy in meters.
member.remarks: The Windows Location Provider and the Windows Phone Location Services accuracy depends on the location data available. For example,iIf Wifi is available, data is accurate to within 50 meters. If Wifi is not available, the data could be accurate to within 10 miles or larger. A GNSS device can provide data accurate to within a few meters. However, its accuracy can vary if the GNSS sensor is obscured by buildings, trees, or cloud cover. GNSS data may not be available at all within a building.

member.name: P:InTheHand.Devices.Geolocation.Geocoordinate.AltitudeAccuracy
member.summary: The accuracy of the altitude, in meters.
member.value: The accuracy of the altitude.
member.remarks: It is optional for a location provider to set this property. If the property is not provided, the value will be NULL. The Windows Location Provider and the Windows Phone Location Services do not set this property.

member.name: P:InTheHand.Devices.Geolocation.Geocoordinate.Heading
member.summary: The current heading in degrees relative to true north.
member.value: The current heading in degrees relative to true north.
member.remarks: It is optional for a location provider to set this property. If the property is not provided, the value will be NULL. The Windows Location Provider does not set this property.

member.name: P:InTheHand.Devices.Geolocation.Geocoordinate.Point
member.summary: The location of the Geocoordinate.
member.value: The location of the Geocoordinate.

member.name: P:InTheHand.Devices.Geolocation.Geocoordinate.PositionSource
member.summary: Gets the source used to obtain a Geocoordinate.
member.value: The source used to obtain a Geocoordinate.

member.name: P:InTheHand.Devices.Geolocation.Geocoordinate.PositionSourceTimestamp
member.summary: Gets the time at which the associated Geocoordinate position was calculated.
member.value: The time at which the associated Geocoordinate position was calculated.
member.remarks:
When this property is not available, the value will be null.
The timestamp returned by this property depends on how the location was obtained and may be completely unrelated to the system time on the device. For example, if the position is obtained from the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) the timestamp would be obtained from the satellites. If the position was is obtained from Secure User Plane Location (SUPL), the timestamp would be obtained from SUPL servers. This means that the timestamps obtained from these services will be precise and, most importantly, consistent across all devices regardless of whether the system time on the devices is set correctly.

member.name: P:InTheHand.Devices.Geolocation.Geocoordinate.Speed
member.summary: The speed in meters per second.
member.value: The speed in meters per second.
member.remarks: It is optional for a location provider to set this property. If the property is not provided, the value will be NULL. The Windows Location Provider does not set this property.

member.name: P:InTheHand.Devices.Geolocation.Geocoordinate.Timestamp
member.summary: The system time at which the location was determined.
member.value: The system time at which the location was determined.

member.summary: No connectivity.

member.summary: Local network access only.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Networking.Connectivity.NetworkConnectivityLevel.ConstrainedInternetAccess
member.summary:
Limited internet access.
This value indicates captive portal connectivity, where local access to a web portal is provided, but access to the Internet requires that specific credentials are provided via the portal. This level of connectivity is generally encountered when using connections hosted in public locations (e.g. coffee shops and book stores). Note This doesn't guarantee detection of a captive portal. Windows Store apps should also test if the captive portal can be reached using a URL for the captive portal, or by attempting access to a public web site which will then redirect to the captive portal when Windows reports LocalAccess as the current NetworkConnectivityLevel.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Networking.Connectivity.NetworkConnectivityLevel.InternetAccess
member.summary: Local and Internet access.

member.name: T:InTheHand.System.Display.DisplayRequest
member.summary: Represents a display request.
member.remarks:
To conserve power and extend battery life, the system reduces power to the computer if it does not detect any user activity for a certain amount of time. Depending on system power settings, the display may first be dimmed, a screen saver may be displayed, and eventually the display may be turned off as the system enters a low-power sleep state.
PlatformVersion supported
AndroidAndroid 4.4 and later
iOSiOS 9.0 and later
tvOStvOS 9.0 and later
Windows UWPWindows 10
Windows StoreWindows 8.1 or later
Windows Phone StoreWindows Phone 8.1 or later
Windows Phone SilverlightWindows Phone 8.0 or later
Windows (Desktop Apps)Windows 7 or later

member.name: T:InTheHand.UI.Popups.MessageDialog
member.summary: Represents a dialog.
member.remarks:
The dialog has a command bar that can support up to three commands. If you don't specify any commands, then a default command is added to close the dialog.
The dialog dims the screen behind it and blocks touch events from passing to the app's canvas until the user responds.
Message dialogs should be used sparingly, and only for critical messages or simple questions that must block the user's flow.

iOSiOS 9.0 and later
macOSOS X 10.7 and later
tvOStvOS 9.0 and later

Windows Phone StoreWindows Phone 8.1 or later

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class to display a titled message dialog box that can be used to ask your user simple questions.
member.param: The message you want displayed to the user.
The title you want displayed on the dialog box.

member.name: M:InTheHand.UI.Popups.MessageDialog.ShowAsync
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous operation showing a dialog.
member.returns: An object that represents the asynchronous operation. For more on the async pattern, see Asynchronous programming in the Windows Runtime.
member.remarks: In some cases, such as when the dialog is closed by the system out of your control, your result can be an empty command. Returns either the command selected which destroyed the dialog, or an empty command. For example, a dialog hosted in a charms window will return an empty command if the charms window has been dismissed.

member.name: P:InTheHand.UI.Popups.MessageDialog.Commands
member.summary: Gets the set of commands that appear in the command bar of the message dialog.
member.remarks: This is the array of commands that makes the dialog actionable. Get this array and add your dialog commands to it.
member.value: The commands.

member.name: P:InTheHand.UI.Popups.MessageDialog.Content
member.summary: Gets or sets the message to be displayed to the user.
member.value: The message to be displayed to the user.
member.remarks:
Use the content to convey the objective of the dialog. Present the message, error or blocking question as simply as possible without extraneous information.
When a title is used, use the content to present additional information helpful to understanding or using the dialog. You can use this area to provide more detail or define terminology. Don't repeat the title with slightly different wording.

member.name: P:InTheHand.UI.Popups.MessageDialog.CancelCommandIndex
member.summary:
Gets or sets the index of the command you want to use as the cancel command. This is the command that fires when users press the ESC key.
Add the commands before you set the index.

member.name: P:InTheHand.UI.Popups.MessageDialog.DefaultCommandIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the index of the command you want to use as the default. This is the command that fires by default when users press the ENTER key instead of a specific command, for example.
member.remarks: Add the commands before you set the index.
member.value: The index of the default command.

member.name: P:InTheHand.UI.Popups.MessageDialog.Title
member.summary: Gets or sets the title to display on the dialog box, if any.
member.value: The title you want to display on the dialog. If the title is not set, this will return an empty string.
member.remarks:
Use the title as a concise main instruction to convey the objective of the dialog.
Long titles do not wrap and will be truncated.
If you're using the dialog to deliver a simple message, error or question, omit the title. Rely on the to deliver that core information.
